array.string:
The Definite Article "The"
  • Do not put 'the' before names of substances if they are used in a general sense.
Correct Sentence:
Gold is precious metal.
Incorrect Sentence:
The Gold is a precious metal
But "the" must be used if the reference is to a particular kind.
Eg:
The gold mined here is of poor quality .

The Definite Article "The"
Do not put "the" before names of meals if they are used in a general sense.
Correct Sentence:
Breakfast is at eight o'clock.
Incorrect Sentence:
The breakfast is at eight o'clock.
But "the" must be used if the reference is to a particular kind.
Eg:
The dinner will be held at the Taj .
The is also used when the name of the meal refers to the food rather than the occasion.
Eg: We enjoyed the breakfast she gave us.

The Definite Article "The"
Do not put the before plural nouns when they are used in general sense.
Correct Sentence:
Apples are grown in many different countries.
Books are essential to a student.
Incorrect Sentence:
The apples are grown in many different countries.
The books are essential to a student.

The Definite Article "The"
  • Do not put "the" before names of games.
Incorrect Sentence:
I play the football.
Correct Sentence:
I play football.

The Definite Article "The"
Do not use "the" before names of countries unless country is made of smaller units.
Incorrect Sentence:
The japan.
kingdom of Saudi Arabia
Correct Sentence:
Japan.
The kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

The Definite Article "The"
Do not use "the" before the words "Queen" and "King" if they are followed by the name of the king or queen.
Incorrect Sentence:
The Queen Victoria.
Correct Sentence:
Queen Victoria.

The Definite Article "The"
"The" is not used before names ending in Street,Avenue,Cresent or Lane.
Incorrect Sentence:
Nelson's monument is in the Trafalgar Square.
Correct Sentence:
Nelson's monument is in the Trafalgar Square.

The Definite Article "The"
Put "the" before nouns which name the inhabitants of a country collectively but not before the language they speak
Incorrect Sentence:
French live in France
Russians sent up the first earth satellite.
The Spanish is spoken in Spain.
Correct Sentence:
The French live in france.
The Russians sent up the first earth satellite.
Spanish is spoken in Spain.

The Definite Article "The"
Use "the" before names of rivers, canals, seas, oceans, valleys, deserts and forests.
Incorrect Sentence:
London is on  Thames.
Correct Sentence:
London is on the Thames.

The Definite Article "The"
"The" is left out in expressions "all day" and "all night".
"The" is used for other divisions of time: all the morning,all the afternoon,all the week.
Incorrect Sentence:
I have worked hard all the day.
It has been raining all morning.
Correct Sentence:
I have worked hard all day.
It has been raining all the morning.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
When the subject is "one of" ,followed by a plural noun, the verb is singular.
Incorrect Sentence:
One of my teachers are on leave.
Correct Sentence:
One of my teachers is on leave.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
When a clause or group of words separate the subject
from the verb,the actual subject has to agree with the verb.
Incorrect Sentence:
The radio which you gave my children work perfectly.
Correct Sentence:
The radio which you gave my children works perfectly.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
When the subject is the formal "there",the verb agrees with the 'real' subject that follows it.
Incorrect Sentence:
There is thirty pupils in our class.
Correct Sentence:
There are thirty pupils in our class.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
When a subject consists of two or more nouns,it takes a plural verb .
Correct Sentence:
Rice,barley and wheat are cereals.

But when two or more nouns represent a compound name of one thing,it takes a singular subject.
Incorrect Sentence
Bread and butter are wholesome food.
Correct Sentence:
Bread and butter is a wholesome food.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
Usually distance, weights and amounts of money are treated as singular and takes a singular verb.

Incorrect Sentence
Ten pounds are a lot of money.
Correct Sentence:
Ten pounds is a lot of money.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
Words such as
  • eithier
  • neithier
  • everyone
  • everybody
  • anyone 
  • each 
  • none
  • somebody
  • someone
are singular
Incorrect Sentence
Everyone are fine.
Correct Sentence:
Everyone is fine.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
Words such as
  • eithier
  • neithier
  • everyone
  • everybody
  • anyone 
  • each 
  • none
  • somebody
  • someone
are singular.
Incorrect Sentence
Everyone are fine.
Correct Sentence:
Everyone is fine.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
Two singular subjects connected with or or nor are always singular and need a singular verb.  Incorrect Sentence
My mother or father are going to call me.
Correct Sentence:
My mother or father is going to call me.

Subject-Verb-Agreement
If one of the subjects is plural use plural verb and put the plural subject closest to the verb.
Incorrect Sentence
The general or his advisors is responsible for the decision.
Correct Sentence:
The general or his advisors are responsible for the decision.

Nouns:Singular or plural? Some special cases
Collective nouns such as a group, a crowd,a regiment are usually singular and they take a singular verb. 
Incorrect Sentence
group of people were standing at the end.
Correct Sentence:
A group of people was standing at the end.

Nouns:Singular or plural? Some special cases
A pair of when applied to things where two components are always thought of together( scissors,shears,shoes,gloves) is always singular.
Incorrect Sentence
That pair of shoes belong to me .
Correct Sentence:
That pair of shoes belongs to me.

If we omit the words "a pair of" and merely use the plural word, then it must a plural verb.
Eg:Those scissors belong to me.

Nouns:Singular or plural? Some special cases
People and cattle are always plural.
Incorrect Sentence
The cattle was grazing in the meadow.
Correct Sentence:
The cattle were grazing in the meadow.

Nouns:Singular or plural? Some special cases
News is always singular.
Advice is never plural.
Incorrect Sentence
No news are good news.
He gave me many good advice.
Correct Sentence:
No news is good news.
He gave me much good advice.

Nouns:Singular or plural? Some special cases
Names of certain sciences or branches of knowledge which end in -s are also singular:Mathematics,Physics,etc.
Note:
When mathematics means 'mathematical calculations', the words are plural
Incorrect Sentence
The area of the room is 160 square feet,if my mathematics is correct.
Correct Sentence:
The area of the room is 160 square feet,if my mathematics are correct

Use of "of"
One of, as well as many of ,several of  must be followed by a plural noun.

Incorrect Sentence
One of the boy in our class has won a prize.
Correct Sentence:
One of the boys in our class has won a prize.

Use of "of"
"Some of","half of" take a plural verb if the reference is to things that are countable (i.e.,countables).
Incorrect Sentence
Some of the house is not fit to live in.
Correct Sentence:
Some of the houses are not fit to live in.
They take a singular verb if the reference is to amount or quantity.
Incorrect Sentence:
Half of the land were uncultivated.
Correct Sentence:
Half of the land is uncultivated.

Use of "of"
The "majority of" can be used only for number(i.e, for countable nouns).
"Most of" is used with uncountable nouns.
Correct Sentence:
The majority of the boys like playing cricket.
Most of the stain came out of the dress.

Use of "of"
"Many of" refers to countable nouns and is plural;
"Much of" refers to amount or quantity and is singular.

Correct Sentence:
Many of the flowers are dead.
Much of the countryside was under water.

Use of "of"
When "of" is followed by nouns such as clothing, furniture, lugguage, traffic, crockery, which is singular, it cannot be preceded by a word denoting countable nouns and has to preceded by a word denoting uncountable nouns.
"Much of" refers to amount or quantity and is singular.
Incorrect Sentence:
Several of my clothing has been damaged.
Many of the furniture is old fashioned.
Few of the crockery has been broken.
Majority of the traffic goes by the main road.
Correct Sentence:
Some of my clothing has been damaged.
Much of the furniture is old fashioned.
Little of the crockery has been broken.
Most of the traffic goes by the main road.

Nouns,pronouns and possessive adjectives.
An animal is usually referred to by the neuter "it".
Correct Sentence:
Dont annoy the bull,or it may attack you.

Nouns,pronouns and possessive adjectives.
"Every" and words beginning with every- are singular and must therefore be referred to by the singular pronouns.
Incorrect Sentence:
Every student passed their exam.
Correct Sentence:
Every student passed his exam.

The possessive adjective or the definite article when denoting parts of the body?
When reference is a general one, and no specific person is indicated,then "the" must be used.
Correct Sentence:
Drugs have a tendency to dull the brain and affect the heart.

The possessive adjective or the definite article when denoting parts of the body?
When reference is a particular person ,the possesive adjective(his,her) is required.
Incorrect Sentence:
She has cut the finger.
Hold out the hand.
Correct Sentence:
She has cut her finger.
Hold out her hand.

The possessive adjective or the definite article when denoting parts of the body?
The names of ailments and diseases of parts of the body always have "the" before the part of the body concerned.
Eg:
Cancer of the lung.
Inflamation of the troat.

Confusion of adverbs and adjectives.
The verbs
  1. To seem to
  2. to become
  3. to appear
  4. to feel
  5. to look
  6. to grow
  7. to turn
are followed by adjective and not by adverbs
 Incorrect Sentence:
She became very angrily.
The milk turned sourly.

Confusion of adverbs and adjectives.
An adjective not an adverb is used after verbs such as feel,sound,taste,smell to denote a quality to be experienced. Incorrect Sentence:
The surface of this table feels roughly.
This fruit tastes bitterly.
Correct Sentence
The surface of this table feels rough.
This fruit tastes bitter.

Much Thanks vs Many Thanks?
Thanks is plural count nouns.
"Many" is used for countable nouns.
 Correct:
Many thanks.
Incorrect:
Much thanks.

Confusion of adverbs and adjectives.
An adjective not an adverb is used after verbs such as feel,sound,taste,smell to denote a quality to be experienced. Incorrect Sentence:
The surface of this table feels roughly.
This fruit tastes bitterly.
Correct Sentence
The surface of this table feels rough.
This fruit tastes bitter.

Fairly and rather
"Fairly" is used before positive adverbs and adjectives and is used to denote something which is considered desirable.
"Rather" can be used for things eithier desirable or are viewed with disapproval.
  Incorrect Sentence:
The lecture was fairly boring.
The lecture was rather interesting.
Correct Sentence
The lecture was rather boring
The lecture was farily interesting.

Who and whom
Use "who" when it is the subject of a sentence.
Use "whom" when it is the object of a preposition.
Eg:
Who told you that story? (subject)
She is a person whom everybody likes. (object).
Note:
When you are trying to decide whether to use who or whom,ask yourself if the answer to the question would be "he" or "him".
For example:
Whom do you love?
I love him.
When the answer to the question is "him" use "whom" otherwise use "who".

Much and many
"Much" is used for non-countable nouns.
"Many" is used for countable nouns.
Example:
Many of my friends are learning English.(Friends can be counted).
Much of the land is uncultivated. (Land cannot be counted.)

Still vs Yet
"Still" denotes the continuance of some activity or situation from the past into the present.
"Yet" presents the present situation in relation to the future.
 Examples:
It is still raining.(i.e it was raining previously and it has not stopped.).
The train is due yet (i.e the train is due later.)

Yet is usually placed at the end of the sentence or clause, though this is not a rule.
Example:
Some of the guests have not yet arrived.

Do vs Make
We use the verb 'do' when someone performs an action,activity or task.
We use the verb 'Make' for constructing,building or creating.
 Examples:
Do your work.
Make food.
Note:
'Make' refers to activities which create something that you can touch.

Incorrect uses of SHUT
We can only shut something that is open( a door,a window,one's eyes).
Incorrect Sentence:
Shut up the tap.
Shut up the electric light.
Correct Sentence:
Turn off the tap.
Turn off the electric light.

Using the word 'one'
To avoid repeating a noun,we often use the word 'one' to replace it.
"One" is used only with countable nouns.
Incorrect Sentence:
Do you prefer white wine or red one?
Correct Sentence:
Do you prefer white wine or red?

Using the word 'one'
One is always used in conjunction with an adjective preceded by the article 'a' or 'an' or possessive adjectives like 'your','their',etc.
Incorrect Sentence:
Take off your blue dress and put on green one.
Correct Sentence:
Take off your blue dress and put on your green one.

Since vs For
"Since" refers to the starting point of an action in the past.
"For" refers to a period in time.
Since is always used with present perfect.
Incorrect Sentence:
She is absent since last monday.
I have been waiting here since two hours.
Correct Sentence:
She has been absent since last monday.
I have been waiting here for two hours.

Reflexive pronoun:
Reflexive pronouns are used when the object and the subject of a sentence are same.
Incorrect Sentence:
She invited my wife and myself for the dinner.
I'm fine and yourself?
Correct Sentence:
She invited my wife and me for the dinner.
I'm fine and you?
Since the subject is "She" and not "I", the object and subject in the sentence are not the same.

a vs an:
Use 'a' before nouns that start with a consonant sound.
Use 'an' before nouns that start with a vowel sound.
Example
Please give the dog a cookie.
Note:
an hour
hour is pronounced like "our"which gives a vowel sound.
A union
Union is pronounced as you-ion.So 'a' is used.

Anyhow vs Somehow:
Somehow means "by some means"
Anyhow means "for certain".
Incorrect Sentence:
I managed to do anyhow.
Correct Sentence:
I managed to do somehow.

Question tag:
Question tag is a mini question at the end of the sentence.
Example
Snow is white.Isn't it?
You dont like me, do you?
Note:
The question tag after "I am" is Aren't I?

No sooner
When "no sooner" comes at the beginning of a sentence, we use inverted word order.
Incorrect Sentence:
No sooner I had reached the station than the train left.
Correct Sentence:
No sooner had i reached the station than the train left.

Using "but"
"But" is used in a sentence to introduce unexpected results.
Incorrect Sentence:
Their front door was open and there was nobody at home.
Correct Sentence:
Their front door was open but there was nobody at home.

Dangling participle
Dangling participle are tricky word or phrases that change the meaning of the sentence.
Incorrect Sentence:
hiking the trail,the birds chirped loudly.
It seems that the birds are hiking the trail.

Correct Sentence:
hiking the trail,she heard the birds chirping loudly.

Dangling participle
Dangling participle are tricky word or phrases that change the meaning of the sentence.
Incorrect Sentence:
Rushing to catch the bus, Bob's wallet fell out of his packet.
Walking along the beach, the sun rose majestically over.

Explanation:
It seems that bob's wallet was rushing to catch the bus.
The sun does not walk along the beach

The Expression of Time
"At" is used for certain moment or point in time.
Example
The train leaves at 2.45pm
We had breakfast at 8'o clock.

The Expression of Time
"On" is used for a specific day.
Example
I will come on Friday.
She was born on August 15,1999.

The Expression of Time
"In" is used before words which denote a period of time.
Example
We first came here in 1962.
We shall be ready in a few minutes.
Come back early in an hour's time.

The Expression of Time
"During" is used to express the idea:
    That an occurrence continues,or a situation persists,throughout the whole of a specified period.
     That an event took place within the specified course of time.
Example
During the war,the food was rationed.
I will call you during the week.

The Expression of Time
"By" is used to denote the latest time by which something was or is to be done.It may done before before, but not after.
Example
You must come here by ten o'clock.
The work should be finished by next friday.

The Expression of Time
The prepositions at,on and in' are not used if the noun giving a time is preceded by an adjective.
Incorrect Sentence.
I met him on last friday.
She will be eighteen in next july.
The doctor calls to see him on every day.
Correct Sentence:
I met him last friday.
She will be eighteen next july.
The doctor calls to see him everyday.

The Expression of Time
Yesterday,today and tomorrow are also used as adverbs and do not take a preposition.
Incorrect Sentence.
She promised to come on today.
I will telephone you on tomorrow.
Correct Sentence:
She promised to come today.
I will telephone you tomorrow.

Your vs You're
'Your' shows ownership.
"You're" means 'you are'

Example:
Is it your car?
You're my friend.

Beside vs Besides
Beside means "by side of".
Besides means "in addition to".

Example:
She stood beside me.
Besides being a player,he was my friend.

Pronoun:I
When two pronouns are used in a sentence, 'I' should not come first.
Incorrect Sentence
I and He went to the party.
Correct Sentence
He and I went for the party.

Adverbs or Adjectives.
Adverbs speak more about the verbs.
Adverbs mostly end in 'ly'.
Incorrect Sentence
They behaved cowardly.
Correct Sentence
They behaved in a cowardly manner.
Cowardly is an adjective and not an adverb.So Cowardly cannot come seperately in a sentence.Other examples of adjectives are lovely, deadly, likely, miserly, friendly.

Adverbs or Adjectives.
Adverbs speak more about the verbs.
Adverbs mostly end in 'ly'.
Incorrect Sentence
They behaved cowardly.
Correct Sentence
They behaved in a cowardly manner.

Cowardly is an adjective and not an adverb.
So Cowardly cannot come seperately in a sentence.
Other examples of adjectives are lovely, deadly, likely, miserly, friendly.

Before vs ago.
Before means: at some unknown time before now.
Ago tells us how long before the present time something happened. It tells us when and gives us a time or a date
Example:
Your mother phoned me five minutes back.
Have you been here before.
Incorrect Sentence
Before long there was no one there.
Correct Sentence
Long ago there was no one.

Subtle mistakes.
After the noum, we use a cardinal number(one,two,three,etc).
Incorrect Sentence
She is in class ninth.
Correct Sentence
She is in class nine.

Countable vs non-countable nouns
Before non-countable nouns we use 'some'.
Before countable nouns we use 'a' or 'an'.
Incorrect Sentence
She gave me an advice.
Correct Sentence
She gave me some advice.

Definite article:'the'
We dont use 'the' before companies.
Incorrect Sentence
Bill gates founded the microsoft.
Correct Sentence
Bill gates founded microsoft.

Uncommon Expressions.
The expressions 'very much' and 'very many' are uncommon expressions.
Incorrect Sentence
She is very much beautiful.
She was very foolish enough to trust him.
Correct Sentence
She is very beautiful.
She was so foolish enough to trust him.

Pronoun antedent agreement.
The pronoun must agree in with the antecedent in number.
Incorrect Sentence
Each person must take their coat to the dry cleaner.
All the players must take his coat to the dry cleaner
Correct Sentence
Everyone must take his or her coat to the dry cleaner.
All the players must take their coat to the dry cleaner.

Pronoun:I.
The pronoun 'I' should not be separated from its verb.
Incorrect Sentence
I,with my brother went for a walk.
Correct Sentence
I went for a walk with my brother.

Unless
Unless means: if not
It is uncommon to start sentences with 'if not'.
Incorrect Sentence
Unless you do not give the keys of the safe, you will be shot dead.
Correct Sentence
Unless you give the keys of the safe, you will be shot dead.

Unless already means 'if not'. By adding unless you are negating the sentence.

Using so with Adjectives.
The correct way of using 'so' with adjectives is
So + adjective + a/an +singular countable noun.
Incorrect Sentence
I have never seen a so intelligent girl.
He was a so generous man that he donated all his wealth for charity.
Correct Sentence
I have never seen so a intelligent girl.
He was so generous a man that he donated all his wealth for charity.

Did you know?
The interogative form of I am not is
Arn't I? (informal)
Am I not? (more formal)

Exanples
Am I not good enough to associate with you?
Aren't I good enough to associate with you?

Comparative Degree:
When we compare two different things with a third,and wish to say that one of the two is superior to the third to an even greater degree than the other is, this is expressed by the comparative followed or preceded by "still".
Incorrect Sentence:
William is taller than John,but James is more taller.
Correct Sentence:
William is taller than John,but James is taller still.

Comparative Degree:
Comparative degree is used to compare only two things. If you wish to compare more than two things, You should use the superlative .
Incorrect Sentence:
Of the two languages I am learning, I find English the easiest.
Correct Sentence:
Of the two languages I am learning, I find English the easier.

Degrees of Comparison:Very vs Much
Very is followed by a positive degree.
Much is always followed by a comparative degree.
Incorrect Sentence:
They are so much exciting.
I am feeling very better today.
Correct Sentence:
They are much more exciting.
I am feeling much better today.

Expressions of Time: in vs at
A speaker will use 'in' if he identifies himself in place,eithier because he identifies himself with the place,eithier because he lives there or because he happens to be there at the time of speaking.
Incorrect Sentence:
have you lived at Chennai long?
Correct Sentence:
Have you lived in Chennai long?

Omissions of Prepositions
Intransitive verbs cannot take an object on its own.So a prepostion must not be omitted.
Incorrect Sentence
She pointed the tree.
Correct Sentence:
She pointed at the tree.

Omissions of Prepositions
In sentences which begin with an interrogative word like what? which? who? where?,care must be taken not to omit the preposition which goes at the end, immediately after the verb.
Incorrect Sentence
What is the teacher looking?
Correct Sentence:
What is the teacher looking for?

Use of prepositions where none is required.
Transitive verbs do not require a preposition to link it to the object.
Incorrect Sentence
She refused to answer to me.
The dog attacked against the child.
Correct Sentence:
She refused to answer me.
The dog attacked the child.
'Answer and attacked' are transitive verbs.

Common Errors while using conjunctions.
When you combine two sentences, you should have only one conjunction.
Incorrect Sentence
Although she was tired,but she still sent on working.
Because he transgressed law,so he was punished.
Correct Sentence:
Although she was tired,she still sent on working.
Because he transgressed law,he was punished.
